story:
A little about me

I am the artist known online as Christy "Goldenwolf" Grandjean (and sometimes just Goldenwolf)!  I am a mostly self-taught professional artist well known for my anthropomorphic animal characters and unique whimsical style.  My work is quite visible and wide-spread across the internet and I am currently licensed with The Mountain, Inc. (popular t-shirt company) and I have been published in several magazines and other publications.  My art has even been featured on the hit MTV series "Teen Wolf"!

This is my second sketchbook volume that follows my wildly successful first volume that was put out last year.  These "sketchbooks" are collections of drawings I have done for clients, or friends, or for myself, plus doodles, scribbles, ideas, vignettes, and just plain silliness from my own personal sketchbooks over the years.

I need your help getting funded so that I can cover my costs of printing a first run of these sketchbooks. 

The Sketchbook

Same format and size as Volume 1:
8.5" X 11" Perfect Bound Paperback
Black and White interior
Glossy Full Color Cover 

63 Pages full of my sketches and drawings from over the years, including many never before seen works!  This volume will include many older drawings from as far back as the 90s!  (FYI I will never repeat stuff that has been used in previous volumes so that the art in each of my sketchbooks is fresh)


What I Need, and Perks!

I would like to do an initial printing run of 200 books, which will cost approximately $900 to get printed via lulu.com.  This includes the cost of proofs and the price of shipping all those sketchbooks to me.  Once they are printed they will be available on my website, www.goldenwolfen.com, and at the various art shows and conventions I attend throughout the year.

I am offering a few funding tiers with perks for your contribution:

  • $5 - Thanks for supporting the campaign!  You get my heartfelt gratitude for being awesome!
  • $28 - You will receive an unsigned copy of the sketchbook .  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US. International contributors please add $10 for shipping.
  • $40 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, plus an 8.5" X 11" open edition, unmatted print of your choice from my website.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International contributors please add $10 for shipping.
  • $50 - You will receive a signed copy of both Volume 1 and Volume 2 of the sketchbooks.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International please add $12 for shipping.
  • $60 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, and two 8.5" X 11" open edition, unmatted prints from my website.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International contributors please add $12 for shipping.
  • $75 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, a matted 11" X 14" open edition print of your choice from my website, and a t-shirt from my website.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International contributors please add $25 US for shipping.
  • $100 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, an 8.5" X 11" unmatted print of your choice from my website, and a custom sketch in pencil on the inside of the sketchbook!  Two-word descriptions only, such as "Anthro Wolf", "Werewolf", "Tiger Dude", "Fire Dragon", "Fairy Princess", etc.  These will be rough sketches on a blank page just inside the cover.  Please be non-specific, I will not do a sketch named "my character" or anything like that.  Allow an additional 6 - 8 weeks for delivery after the sketchbooks are printed.  International contributors please add $10 for shipping.

Stretch Goal #1 - Achieved! Limited Edition Sketchbook!

We've reached our first stretch goal of $2,000, which means that the sketchbook now becomes a Special Edition sketchbook just for IndieGoGo contributors!  Everyone who contributes to this campaign will now receive the Special Edition sketchbook which will feature a new drawing done exclusively for this edition!  Thank you all again for your enthusiastic support!

Stretch Goal #2 - Achieved!  Colored Centerfold!

We've reached our second stretch goal of $5,000, which means I will now be coloring this magnificent dragon (which will be a full two-page spread) which will be the centerfold!  This piece will never be seen in any other book of art that I publish, and though I will make prints available this piece will otherwise be exclusive to the Special Edition sketchbook that every contributor to this campaign will receive!


Shipping

Shipping for all contributors within the US is included in your perk, so no need to send anything additional!  International contributors do need to send a bit more to cover the cost of shipping.  The amount is listed with the perk.  To do that you can send the additional amount as a "no perk" contribution.  Since I learned a great deal with the last campaign I will be handling things in a very efficient manner once the sketchbooks are printed and in my hands.  I should have the sketchbooks by February 2015 and will be shipping perks immediately.  Most everyone should get their perks by March.  International shipping does take a little bit longer, so some of you may see yours in April.  Those getting sketches will get your sketchbooks in April. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  You can spread the word about this campaign to anyone you think might be interested in my sketchbook!

Thanks for checking out my funding campaign!
story_txt:
A little about meI am the artist known online as Christy "Goldenwolf" Grandjean 
(and sometimes just Goldenwolf)!  I am a mostly self-taught professional
 artist well known for my anthropomorphic animal characters and unique 
whimsical style.  My work is quite visible and wide-spread across the 
internet and I am currently licensed with The Mountain, Inc. (popular 
t-shirt company) and I have been published in several magazines and 
other publications.  My art has even been featured on the hit MTV series
 "Teen Wolf"!This is my second sketchbook volume that follows my wildly successful first volume that was put out last year.  These "sketchbooks" are collections of drawings I have done for clients, or friends, or for myself, plus doodles, scribbles, ideas, vignettes, and just plain silliness from my own personal sketchbooks over the years.I need your help getting funded so that I can cover my costs of printing a first run of these sketchbooks.  The SketchbookSame format and size as Volume 1:8.5" X 11" Perfect Bound Paperback Black and White interiorGlossy Full Color Cover 63 Pages full of my sketches and drawings from over the years, including many never before seen works!  This volume will include many older drawings from as far back as the 90s!  (FYI I will never repeat stuff that has been used in previous volumes so that the art in each of my sketchbooks is fresh)
What I Need, and Perks!
I would like to do an initial printing run of 200 books, which will cost
 approximately $900 to get printed via lulu.com.  This includes the cost of proofs and the price of shipping all those sketchbooks to me.  Once they are printed 
they will be available on my website, www.goldenwolfen.com, and at the various art shows and conventions I attend throughout the year.I am offering a few funding tiers with perks for your contribution:
$5 - Thanks for supporting the campaign!  You get my heartfelt gratitude for being awesome!

$28 - You will receive an unsigned copy of the 
sketchbook .  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US. International contributors 
please add $10 for shipping.
$40 - You will receive a signed copy of the 
sketchbook, plus an 8.5" X 11" open edition, unmatted print of your 
choice from my website.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International contributors please add $10 for 
shipping.
$50 - You will receive a signed copy of both Volume 1 and Volume 2 of the sketchbooks.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International please add $12 for shipping.

$60 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, and two 8.5" X 11" open edition, unmatted prints from my website.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International 
contributors please add $12 for shipping.
$75 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, a matted 11" X 14" open edition print of your choice from my website, and a
 t-shirt from my website.  This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies) within the US.  International contributors please add $25 US for shipping.

$100 - You will receive a signed copy of the sketchbook, 
an 8.5" X 11" unmatted print of your choice from my website, and a 
custom sketch in pencil on the inside of the sketchbook!  Two-word 
descriptions only, such as "Anthro Wolf", "Werewolf", "Tiger Dude", 
"Fire Dragon", "Fairy Princess", etc.  These will be rough sketches on a blank page just inside the cover.  Please be non-specific, I will not do a sketch named "my character" or anything like that.  Allow an additional 6 - 8 weeks for delivery 
after the sketchbooks are printed.  International contributors please add $10 
for shipping.

Stretch Goal #1 - Achieved! Limited Edition Sketchbook!
We've reached our first stretch goal of $2,000, which means that the sketchbook now becomes a Special Edition sketchbook just for IndieGoGo contributors!  Everyone who contributes to this campaign will now receive the Special Edition sketchbook which will feature a new drawing done exclusively for this edition!  Thank you all again for your enthusiastic support!Stretch Goal #2 - Achieved!  Colored Centerfold!
We've reached our second stretch goal of $5,000, which means I will now be coloring this magnificent dragon (which will be a full two-page spread) which will be the centerfold!  This piece will never be seen in any other book of art that I publish, and though I will make prints available this piece will otherwise be exclusive to the Special Edition sketchbook that every contributor to this campaign will receive!ShippingShipping for all contributors within the US is included in your perk, so no need to send anything additional!  International contributors do need to send a bit more to cover the cost of shipping.  The amount is listed with the perk.  To do that you can send the additional amount as a "no perk" contribution.  Since I learned a great deal with the last campaign I will be handling things in a very efficient manner once the sketchbooks are printed and in my hands.  I should have the sketchbooks by February 2015 and will be shipping perks immediately.  Most everyone should get their perks by March.  International shipping does take a little bit longer, so some of you may see yours in April.  Those getting sketches will get your sketchbooks in April.  Other Ways You Can HelpI understand that some people just 
can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  You can spread 
the word about this campaign to anyone you think might be interested in 
my sketchbook!Thanks for checking out my funding campaign!

story:
Short Summary

This project will fund a series of paintings called "Identity Workers: Terraforming Faces" between the Chicago-area artists Michael Stidham and Matthew Gilboy. Each piece will center the viewer on the political, social, and economic dynamics of constructing identity in the world at large.

IndieGoGo is a "crowdfunding" platform that allows emerging artists who don't have the backing of galleries or museums to ask for contributions from people like you to help produce their work. Our goal of this summary is to help you understand the message behind our work, what you are considering funding, and how it will reach people.

  1. We will be creating paintings that document 'Identity Work' (concept explained below)
  2. Your funds will go to art supplies, surfaces, and studio space
  3. We will be organizing an exhibition of the work and speaking engagements
Many people, not just people of color or people with disabilities, do Identity Work for the benefit of society. It is isolating work to have to control how you project yourself, and it interferes with the self-awareness tasks we take for granted. These paintings will be evidence to other Identity Workers that they are not alone in the work they do, and will affirm that it is real work that drains you of energy and resources.

Concept

Mike is a black artist. Matt is an artist with epilepsy. Both explore the ways their identity has been shaped by society's reaction to them as such

The series is meant to portray 'Identity Work', the daily work people do to make society feel comfortable. An 'Identity Worker' is someone must modify how they present discomforting parts of their identity; in the case of race or disability, the goal might be to be perceived as not a threat, or not too dependent. This is intense, emotional work that Identity Workers do every day. These paintings will affirm the labor of Identity Workers and document it so that the rest of the world can see what it looks like.

Often, we focus on exceptional people; unfortunately this puts a lot of pressure on the rest of us and our day to day performance of this work. It sets up a dichotomy where some are viewed as less admirable or unworthy. This can isolate people, or foster resentment. These paintings are going to be a tool to help build community around Identity Work, and show that others are doing this work and it is not some solitary struggle.

Still not sure what we mean by Identity Work? Read this, it's an analogy written for Midwesterners, like Mike and Matt.

Three Ways to Help
You can help us in three ways:
  • Donate! It's why we have an IndieGoGo campaign!
  • Get Updated! We've got a contact form here! Like our Facebook pages to keep up to date on our work individually [Mike], [Matthew]
  • Share! Tell people about us with the IGG sharing features!

The "Us" 

We work on large format paintings that are confrontational and challenging for the viewer. Depending on the context, we would both be considered Identity Workers, and we want to foster critical discussions of the “solved” status of Identity Work, specifically around race and disability. This series of pieces intends to portray the continuation of this process of Identity Work, and how its collisions with the normative stare affects Identity Workers.
  • Michael has established himself working in acrylic media creating monumental faces with airbrush and paint, and performing live action painting for audiences. Michael is originally from Cleveland and studied at SAIC.
  • Matt's works primarily in oil paint, but also focuses on detailing internal struggles through portraiture with mixed media pieces using spray paint and paint marker. Matt is originally from Youngstown and studied at YSU.

What We Need & What You Get

Budget Details:

  • Total - $8900
  • Painting Materials for "Terraforming Faces" - $600
  • Expenses - $8300 (studio space, archival scans, perks, etc)
  • For a detailed, line by line budget, you can visit this link
Perks summary:
  • You did good for us
  • You did good for the people we reach
  • You'll get public thanks for that extra contribution
  • You'll get goodies for that - postcards!
  • You'll get a public thank you at the opening
  • MOAR GOODIES! - Limited Edition print of the works!
  • ALL the Goodies, a Spotlight, and your name/logo on the flyer

What will your support look like?

Funds contributed to our campaign not only net you the perks above, but will help us create art and exhibit it for the benefit of Identity Workers.
If we're shy on our goal?
  • Expenses in the budget are listed in order of priority. Although us paying ourselves is pretty critical, it is subordinate to getting funding for surfaces, supplies and spaces. 
  • Basically, our minimum to launch is $4000, but the goal will help ensure the success of the show and continuance of the series

If we exceed our goal?

  • We are looking at this project as having the potential to generate a total of three series of works.
  • The first segment, "Terraforming Faces" is all about how we construct these identities. The second and third segments involve engaging the Stare as an entity on its own, and how specific individuals have dealt with it.
  • If we exceed our goal, we will set aside the additional funds to start funding the other segments.

The Impact

This project is likely to represent a broad base of individuals beyond the boundaries of race or disability. In particular, it is meant to add voice to individuals trampled by the stare of privilege. The aim is to aid in providing a critical framework for discussing the issues around privilege construing identity into some sort of weapon used by social deviants.

Further, it is intended to be engaging for people that do not fall too far outside the boundaries of traditional privilege structures. While this explores issues for those affected by the violence of privilege based on traits like race, gender, sexuality, and disability, it is meant to create a space for people with privilege to come to an understanding of what being without it is like.
Contributing to our project will help us continue building out this critical framework.

Risks & Challenges

We have blindspots. We cannot pretend to represent all people, nor would we want our work to be construed as demonstrating more than what we have experienced. Each person has unexamined privilege somewhere.

Our obligation is to be critical of ourselves, to call out our own problematic behaviors, and accept criticism when it happens. This work you are funding revolves around the creators' collective and individual vulnerabilities in an effort to center viewers on the experience of this labor. We will bring honest work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate:

  • Visit our project page and sign up for updates
  • If you are affected by the kind of identity politics we are working to document, we will be exhibiting and would love to have you come out. Follow us on twitter and facebook to keep up to date.
  • If you feel this project is worth supporting, please use the Indiegogo share tools to post about it on Facebook or Twitter and help foster this conversation

story:
Hello everyone! 

I am FRANCISGUM (Francis Gumayagay). Based in Los Angeles, I am a self-taught published fashion photographer born and raised in the Philippines. I started taking portraits when I moved to Los Angeles. In 2011, I got into fashion photography when a wardrobe stylist asked me to do my first fashion editorial shoot, which also gave me my first magazine published work. 

I have recently been given an amazing opportunity to be part of an arts & culture gallery at the upcoming FESTIVAL OF PHILIPPINE ARTS AND CULTURE at Grand Park in Los Angeles on October 4-5, 2014.  

Festival of Philippine Arts and Culture is the largest annual celebration of Filipino Arts and Culture in Southern California. FPAC is a two-day weekend of arts, culture, fun, and community, and yearly audiences of over 25, 000 intergenerational and multicultural supporters gather, representing 23 years of community tradition.

This is a great honor which is not only a high personal achievement for myself, but will help me expand my audience, and this will open new opportunities for me as a photographer.

With this photo exhibit, I plan to step up and produce a fresh set of images that juxtaposes Filipino culture, pop and fashion. I envision to showcase Filipino craftsmanship in fashion fused with the rich and vibrant heritage of the Philippines.  

It has always been a dream project to do a Filipino-inspired photo exhibit. It’s my way of expressing how proud I am as a Filipino who is living  and achieving his dreams here in Los Angeles as a fashion photographer. And with this opportunity to be part of this festival, this is the best time to produce these images. 

Producing a photo exhibit is costly. In order for me to do this, I will need your HELP. Your financial contribution will greatly help various elements of this project, such as photoshoot production, printing of images and marketing materials and transportation.  

Breakdown of expenses:

Photoshoot Production $200

Printing of Images $300

Transportation $50

Printing of Marketing Materials $100

With your support, you will not only be helping me, but you will also contribute to the success of the festival.

For more information about the festival, visit http://www.filamarts.org/fpac-about/.

You can view my works at http://www.francisgum.com .

I also ask you to SHARE this link http://igg.me/at/francisgumfpac to your friends & family and/or to post this link http://igg.me/at/francisgumfpac to your social media accounts. It will greatly help in spreading the word.

THANK YOU SO MUCH!

story:
What's Going On?

We believe sexuality should be celebrated, not hidden away as a dirty secret. Sex is fun! There, we said it!

Artists and art lovers will come together for a creative, provocative weekend at the Rochester Erotic Arts Festival on March 30-31, 2012 at the Radisson Riverside Hotel in downtown Rochester NY.

The Erotic Art Show and Sale presents a unique opportunity for artists to market their work to an appreciative adult audience.

Not just an art show, the festival showcases erotic entertainment like classically bawdy burlesque, aerial arts, sultry singing, bellydance and Shibari rope bondage. This year we are thrilled to include a showing of the internationally known CineKink film shorts, which explore the exciting world of sexual diversity.

An electrifying performance of erotic poetry... tattoo contest... body painting... workshops on topics as diverse as erotic tickling, body casting, pole dancing, belly dance, erotic hypnosis, sensation play, live model drawing, and bedroom photography. Our vending area offers creative and artistic jewelry, clothing, and yes! sex toys, as well as an opportunity to engage with alternative communities in the area.

Where Will Your Money Go?

By donating to this campaign you are giving artists from all over the US a rare opportunity to exhibit and sell their erotic works. Our goal is to raise $3200 to cover the space rental for this event. This will allow us to use our income (from ticket sales, artist fees and vending) for art awards, performing artists, workshop presenters and contest prizes. Donations above and beyond our goal will ensure the financial stability of the festival, enabling us to continue this exciting event in future years.

Every donation, no matter how large or small, is very important! After the first $1000 in individual donations, REAF will become eligible to apply for a $2500 grant through Fractured Atlas. The application deadline is December 31, so we need to raise our first $1000 in the next month. Please help us reach our goal! Your investment in the festival could be doubled or more through this opportunity!



Some of you may be wondering, is my money supporting porn? What is the difference between porn and erotic art? While the definition of erotic art changes from age to age and community to community, the underlying basis of erotic art is its thought-provoking nature. And while erotic art and porn can both make you hot, erotic art engages a much deeper emotional response.


Who Are We?

The festival is produced by the sex-positive non-profit corporation Rochester Erotic Arts, Inc. We are a member of the Arts and Cultural Council for Greater Rochester (NY) and are a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. This is our third festival, and we have an excellent relationship with our venue, the Radisson Riverside Hotel in downtown Rochester. Our mantra is celebrating sexuality through the arts!


How Else Can You Help?

1) Bring your friends to the festival - increasing our attendance is the single most important factor in ensuring the continued success of the festival!

2) Submit your erotic art and spread the word about our Call for Art - Deadline is February 2, 2012

3) Visit our web site at www.rochestereroticartfest.org

4) Post our banners on your web site

5) Like us on Facebook

6) Follow us on Twitter

story:
Our Story

Hi Everyone, my name is Ben Graham-Putter and I am one of the Co-Founders of BrickHaus Art Space, a Baltimore-based art center that is committed to fostering personal and professional artistic development through studio space, shared technical facilities, gallery space, and a forum for critique and lectures.

My friend Adam Farkas and I had just graduated from art school and were looking for studio spaces in the area, but were unable to find adequate facilities at a price we could afford. It was shortly after this realization that we decided that if we couldn't find such a space, we needed to make one. After a month or two of searching, we found an old storage warehouse in Baltimore City's Harwood neighborhood. With 15,000 square feet, plenty of windows, and a freight elevator that could fit a car, this space was exactly what we were looking for.

In March of 2011 we moved in and got to work. The project has taken a huge amount of personal energy, and has been the destination of every extra dollar either of us have earned. Between the two of us, we have put in over $35,000 and countless hours making BrickHaus what it is today, a growing community of artists working in one space, sharing ideas, and inspiring one another.


The Impact

We are currently struggling to keep the building warm for our artists, but the space heaters just aren't doing it. We managed to get 4 heating units to heat our spaces, and everything is ready to be hooked up. All we needed was gas service. We had budgeted for about $75 to restart our gas service (this is the figure we got from the website), but when we heard from our utility company that our existing service line was outdated, that number jumped to the $5,000 - $7,000 range! We have managed to do a lot with the money that we have, but this is outside of our ability to fund ourselves.

It is quite a testament to our resident artists that they have been working in their studios everyday despite the cold temperatures, but it is only getting colder and this winter will get very tough without our heat being turned on. I am concerned that without heat, we will be unable to work, and unable to make art, which will be a huge hit to our organization.


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $7,000 to install a new gas service to our building. The money will pay for digging up the road, and connecting our building to the main gas line. It will also pay for a gas meter (only about $75 worth of the overall cost). If we cannot reach our goal, the money we do raise will still go to this project and we will have to find another way (loans, selling stuff, working nights) to fund the remainder of the project.

Anyone who is able to donate to this project will get their name on our website in a special thanks section, and those who give over $30 will receive a logo t-shirt. The $250 giving level will also receive a personal thank you card from all of us here at BrickHaus. For donations larger than $1000 you will also get your name on a plaque in our gallery.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about our cause! Tweet us! Facebook us! We can't do this without your help and support, and if you can't personally give, maybe you know someone who can. Get the word out, and help BrickHaus stay Mighty!


Thank you!
story_txt:
Our StoryHi Everyone, my name is Ben Graham-Putter and I am one of the Co-Founders of BrickHaus Art Space, a Baltimore-based art center that is committed to fostering personal and professional artistic development 
through studio space, shared technical 
facilities, gallery space, and a forum for critique and lectures. My friend Adam Farkas and I had just graduated from art school and were looking for studio spaces in the area, but were unable to find adequate facilities at a price we could afford. It was shortly after this realization that we decided that if we couldn't find such a space, we needed to make one. After a month or two of searching, we found an old storage warehouse in Baltimore City's Harwood neighborhood. With 15,000 square feet, plenty of windows, and a freight elevator that could fit a car, this space was exactly what we were looking for. In March of 2011 we moved in and got to work. The project has taken a huge amount of personal energy, and has been the destination of every extra dollar either of us have earned. Between the two of us, we have put in over $35,000 and countless hours making BrickHaus what it is today, a growing community of artists working in one space, sharing ideas, and inspiring one another. 

The Impact 
We are currently struggling to keep the building warm for our artists, but the space heaters just aren't doing it. We managed to get 4 heating units to heat our spaces, and everything is ready to be hooked up. All we needed was gas service. We had budgeted for about $75 to restart our gas service (this is the figure we got from the website), but when we heard from our utility company that our existing service line was outdated, that number jumped to the $5,000 - $7,000 range! We have managed to do a lot with the money that we have, but this is outside of our ability to fund ourselves.It is quite a testament to our resident artists that they have been working in their studios everyday despite the cold temperatures, but it is only getting colder and this winter will get very tough without our heat being turned on. I am concerned that without heat, we will be unable to work, and unable to make art, which will be a huge hit to our organization.

What We Need & What You Get 
We are looking to raise $7,000 to install a new gas service to our building. The money will pay for digging up the road, and connecting our building to the main gas line. It will also pay for a gas meter (only about $75 worth of the overall cost). If we cannot reach our goal, the money we do raise will still go to this project and we will have to find another way (loans, selling stuff, working nights) to fund the remainder of the project.Anyone who is able to donate to this project will get their name on our website in a special thanks section, and those who give over $30 will receive a logo t-shirt. The $250 giving level will also receive a personal thank you card from all of us here at BrickHaus. For donations larger than $1000 you will also get your name on a plaque in our gallery.

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word about our cause! Tweet us! Facebook us! We can't do this without your help and support, and if you can't personally give, maybe you know someone who can. Get the word out, and help BrickHaus stay Mighty!

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

You all know me. I moved to CA for art jobs. I was living with a guy for two weeks who had offered me his guest room. Suddenly, he came into my room and informed me that I had to leave immediately, because - I AM NOT EVEN EXAGGERATING THIS - my friend who is a comedian made a self-deprecating joke about being overweight and gay on his facebook. This dude flipped his lid, screamed at me, and said I cavort with "bullies".

Yeah it really is that crazy. I could not have made this up if I tried. So anyway, I'm getting an apartment immediately. I'm still doing freelance work. I'm not totally down and out just yet. But a little donation would go a long way, to help me move, buy food, whatever.

What We Need & What You Get

I just need moneys and a safe place to live without psychos. You get the satisfaction of knowing you helped me not end up in the gutter.

    The Impact

    If you know me, you know I do digital illustration and graphic design. You might recognize my work for the James Randi Foundation or Skeptic Ink, if you're a skeptic. I have art featured in the Advocate promoting equality for gay people. You can see my work at: www.meteodesigns.com

    The impact of you helping would simply be that I worry a bit less and can get everything sorted out as quickly as possible, to continue my freelance work and searching for full-time day jobs.

      Risks & Challenges

      I might have to get a cheap apartment in downtown LA which is stabville, but I'm trying to find something relatively safe and affordable.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Just say hi, be nice to me, I'm kind of vulnerable and very bewildered at the moment. :)

story:
Our Story

Ruben Gonzales - an artist and small business owner of 11th Monk3y, Erik Erspamer - an artist and teacher, other local artists and bike enthusiasts have teamed up to create the Art In Motion project.  Our project team will work with high school students in Phoenix, Arizona to build art bikes for the Scottsdale Public Art – Canal Convergence in November 2013.  The art bikes will be utilized during the bike parade, parked as freestanding sculptures and to host art activities.  After the Canal Convergence the bikes will be part of an exhibition at the Scottsdale Museum of Contemporary Art (SMoCA) and on display during First Fridays at Roosevelt Row in Phoenix, Arizona.

Art bikes are an exciting intersection of the arts and sciences that require students to work collaboratively to combine fine art, design, math and engineering skills. We will be working with local artists, bike enthusiasts and other art students to design and build kinetic works of art.

Our goal is to design and build two (2) art bikes and one (1) multiuse art bike with an attached gallery and project center. Our wish is to inspire Canal Convergance visitors to create and contribute to our art bikes and gallery. 

We will start designing and building the art bikes in August 2013 and complete them by the end of October 2013.  Check our Updates section frequently for design notes and progress photos of our bikes.

Awesome art bikes on the web:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_bike

http://www.austinbikezoo.org/

What We Need

Your support is crucial to bring our art bike designs to life!  We have already been hard at work collecting donated bikes, scrap metal and welding supplies.  Now we need to purchase bike-related tools, equipment and other various parts (tubes, tires, seats, chains, pedals, etc.) to refurbish the bikes and make them safe for riders.

Our goal is to raise $500.00 to purchase two (2) bicycle repair stands, two (2) sets of bike tools and various bike parts to get our art bikes moving and safe to ride!  See our complete list of tools, equipment and supplies in the gallery section.

Every dollar counts, BUT if we don’t quite make our goal we will reduce the number of tools, equipment and continue to seek local donations.  Reducing the stands and tools will impact how fast we will be able to build the bikes and may require us to eliminate one (1) of the art bikes.   Our hope is to make our stretch goals of building two (2) additional art bikes!!!

Check out the diagram below for more info:

 

What You Get

To thank our amazing and generous supporters!  We are offering some special perks and original artworks produced by our students and local artists. Check out the list on the right or look in the perk section below for a clear breakdown. We will be adding more perks and updating our page so check back often!

 

The Impact

The impact of successfully funding our project is huge!  It will allow 30+ sculpture students to work collaboratively with local artists and enthusiasts to design and build the art bikes.  Additionally, it will allow hundreds of Canal Convergence and Roosevelt Row First Fridays visitors to view, interact, and contribute their own artwork to the art bikes. 

Your support also has lasting effects by allowing our team to continue this project with future team members building additional art bikes and kinetic sculptures!

Check the Updates section regularly for our art bike designs, building progress, exhibition schedules and public artworks.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us spread the word by using the sharing tools on indiegogo.com and email the project link to your friends!

 If you are local to the Phoenix area:

  • Come and join us at the Canal Convergence in November 2013 - http://www.scottsdalepublicart.org/events/canal-convergence/
  • You can donate your extra hand tools or equipment to our project.  Please take a look at our tools and equipment list. Contact us to pick up your items.
  • Although we have already received some great bikes, bike parts and supplies, we could still use more!  Really anything can help and maybe used in our final designs. (seats, pedals, chains, 26” tubes, mirrors, handlebars, etc.) Contact us to pick up your items.

 

Tools, Equipment and Supply List

Bike Tools & Equipment

Bike Parts
  • Master link pliers (MLP-1)
  • Allen wrench, folding set (AWS-11)
  • Pedal wrench (PW-3)
  • Chain whip (SR-1)
  • Bottom bracket cup wrench (BBT-9)
  • Crank removal tool (CCW-5)
  • Crank extractor (CWP-6)
  • Cassette lockring removal tool (FR-5G)
  • Bottom bracket retainer tool (BBT-32)
  • Chain breaker (CT-3)
  • Spoke wrenches
  • Adjustable spoke wrench (SW-10)
  • Wheel truing stand (TS-2)
  • Wheel dishing gauge (WAG-4)
  • Cone wrench set (SCW-13 through SCW-18)
  • Rubber mallet
  • Allen wrench set, metric, 1.5mm-10mm, ball-end type
  • Allen wrench set, SAE, 1/16-3/8″, ball-end type
  • Crescent wrenches, 6″ and 12″
  • Channel-Lock pliers, 6″
  • Needle–nosed pliers
  • Torx wrench, T-25
  • Standard and phillips head screwdrivers
  • 1/4″ drive torque wrench, 0-100 in/lb
  • 1/4″ drive allen bit set, metric
  • Tire spoons

 

  • Bike Repair Stand

 
  • Frame
  • Fork
  • Headset
  • Derailleurs
  • Brakes
  • Brake Levers
  • Shifters
  • Headset
  • Cable guides
  • Cranks
  • Pedals
  • Wheels
  • Chain
  • Seat post
  • Seat
  • Seat clamp
  • Brake hangers
  • Stem
  • Handlebars
  • Tires
  • Tubes

 

  • Mirrors
  • Reflectors
  • Lights
  • Grip tape

 

  • Spray primer
  • Spray paint

story:
In 2005, LithiumDreams Photography slowly moving toward artistic photography leaving the fashion world behind there is more satisfaction and acceptance in that realm of work when it comes to our style of work. My first published pieces were in a magazine out of England called The Serpent in 2007. Moving to Atlanta, Georgia in 2007 gave me more opportunity to show my art is local galleries, LithiumDreams joined forces with Morbidly Beautiful Art bring that next step of creativity to our work. Started networking with fellow alternative and fetish photographers and models we have build a solid network of contacts and associates.
We have grow out of three studios and now  have a large studio in the country outside of Atlanta, allowing me to expand our work and space.  In 2010 LithiumDreams was accepted into the what was called at the time Ikros Art Collective, and our art traveled around the Southeast being displayed in fetish galleries and events.  LithiumDreams was just recently published in Gorgeous Freaks Magazine issue 19,  and show annually at Frolicon art show, Frolicon is an alternative and fetish convention in Atlanta held in the spring. Then in late summer annually show art at the Art of Kink art show held at Fetishcon in Tampa, Fla. Plus work shows in many local art shows annually as well etching a style and respect from fellow artist. Our work is recognized in many states and regions of the US, due to unique outlook and style created from dreams,friends dreams, music and stories. LithiumDreams wants to take this dream even further now.

In Los Angeles there is an art event each year in January, FANFARE-LA erotic art show that promotes and displays erotic works of art to a large audience and we want that audience to see our unique style. November 15th we need to make a decision if our art will be in this art show, We have a large amount of art already edited and ready for printing for this kind of show we are adding to it as much as I can between now and then. My work shows the raw unedited fetish world, it is not all glamour and polished as many photographers want to depict it. The art takes the viewer into the scene and creates emotion so in a still image you are feeling what the person in the pictures is feeling, it is fun and edgy as art should be but it is real and draws you in.
My purpose here is to raise $600.00 to cover resignation and submission cost, printing, framing and shipping both way to the gallery in Los Angeles. I have a proven track record of producing amazing work, I am a member of the RAW artist Atlanta, I am currently show art this month and next month at Doogallery in Atlanta. I want to see my work hanging in this show so bad, but with the on going construction cost of renovation my new studio and the slow down in the art market I need that helping hand. I have a few incentives for any of you that are interested in donating to my cause.For as low as $20.00 I will give you as a thank you an 11 X 14 autographed print of the Embrace, the husband and wife that are modeling in this picture had just married a week before, it was and still is a very memorable shoot. For $50.00 a personal thank you letter and a 10 page binder of 8 X 10 images of images from my erotic art collection. For $100.00 a personal thank you letter, plus the 10 page binder, and limited version 30 minute video of stills and video from erotic shoots plus a quick interview about my work. $600.00 I will travel to you as long as you are in the Southeast and do a personal erotic shoot and video for you.

story:
Darkness in the North: A Collaboration between Erica Lord & (former partner TH)

A Short Summary

Erica Lord and (former partner) TH are beginning a creative alliance of epic proportions! This summer, in partnership with Calgary’s The New Gallery and Edmonton’s The Works: Art & Design Festival, internationally recognized artists Erica Lord and (former partner TH) are collaborating on a series of exciting new works. They have sought this artistic partnership for years and starting in June, they are finally coming together for the first time! During June and July, Lord will be the artist in residence at The New Gallery, John Snow House (Calgary, AB). During this time, the artists will conceptualize the ideas they've outlined together, work with a variety of mediums, and conclude by collaborating and producing a series of new work including photography, video, printmaking, installation, new media, performance, and public interventions. A number of these performance works will be presented at The Works: Art & Design Festival, in Edmonton, June 20-July 2, 2013. The artists’ goal is to create a catalog and exhibition, which will include the documentation of these performances along with the other art pieces they create during this time. Lord and TH are seeking your support to help cover the cost of travel and production of art works, performances, and documentation. The New Gallery has generously supported us with housing and studio space; it is our responsibility to raise funds for the materials, production, and presentation. Please consider helping these two dynamic artists carry out their unique and exciting project by giving your support. In exchange for your help, Lord and (former partner TH)  are offering a number of gifts including art catalogs, Lord/TH stickers and shirts, and limited edition photographs, serigraph and letterpress prints.

Darkness in the North, Full Description

Darkness in the North is a collaborative art project inspired by Bruce Springsteen’s album, Darkness on the Edge of Town; Lord and TH found significant meaning in the songs and stories in Darkness, drawing connections to Indigenous peoples’ relationship with the dark, night, urban and rural experiences and the relationships connecting all of those elements. Using this inspiration as their launching point, the artists will collaborate on a series of new works at the John Snow House, where Lord will live, thanks to the support they are receiving from The New Gallery’s Artist in Residence program.

This project is a first collaboration by the artists, who first became friends several years ago when they were simultaneously highlighted as the feature artists on the Native American Indigenous Cinema and Arts website. Realizing they shared many artistic interests and important connections in their work, they hoped to some day work together—this project would finally allow the opportunity for this long-awaited collaboration.

The artists’ intention is to create a body of work involving ideas drawn from Springsteen’s Darkness album. Drawn to the universality of these stories, the artists found inspiration in the narratives of working class people, love and loss, the passion of youth, the reality of aging, the birth of new and the passing of older generations, individuality, community, and the rebellious spirit— all of these things connect us and helps create our identities. The artists’ process will begin with material experiments and intensive research in and around Calgary and Southern Alberta. They will connect and work with local artists, musicians, and artist run centers to create and present their art works. Lord and TH have planned to create a number of different series in a variety of mediums; their projects will include printmaking, photography, video, performance, site-specific works, and more. Since Lord and (former partner TH) have worked toward this union and collaboration for many years, they are confident that their driven and ambitious spirits will support both the scale and vision of this exciting project.

Erica Lord and (former partner TH) are both interdisciplinary media artists who have exhibited nationally and internationally and in many key exhibitions, they have been featured together. Erica Lord is a mixed-race Alaska Native artist who grew up between interior Alaska and Upper Michigan. TH is from Alberta and a member of the Blood Tribe, currently living and working in Calgary. Friends and colleagues for seven years, this project will be the first time Lord and TH will meet and work together.

What We Need & What You Get

The New Gallery and The Works Festival have generously provided us with the necessary bridge to bring us together at the creative think tank called the John Snow House in lovely Calgary, AB. We found a way to come together, we have the studio and time to develop our ideas, what remains is the production and presentation of the work. Creating and presenting work can get expensive and we have been working hard to come up with funding through every possible avenue; we chose to use IndieGoGo so we could offer some of our work in exchange for your valued support. Any size donation is valued and we’ve chosen a variety of gifts we believe you will like. Our goal of $3000 would cover the majority of our costs; if we are not able to reach our full goal, we will try and maximize the funds we do raise. The more money we raise, the more art we will be able to create and finish; our ideas are abundant, but our resources are limited. We are filled with excitement, creativity, and big ideas! Every donation will help some part of our art production—the more help we receive, the closer we will get to fulfilling our goal. Please consider supporting us in our project and goals; in exchange, you will have a part in the creation of important new works as well as a heartfelt thank you and a unique gift from both artists.

Ever wondered what went into creating an art piece? Your donation would support a variety of things including:

  • Supply and material costs for studio based works
  • Paper and substrate for prints, stickers, & posters
  • Ink and pigment/paint
  • Fabric and sewing materials
  • Photography and video documentation
  • Camera equipment rental—lenses & lighting
  • Audio recording equipment rental
  • Meals
  • Transportation costs 

As a thank you for your support, we are offering:

  • La Revolución! Stickers
  • GIVN'R- Perk pulled, alternatives currently being offered*
  • Danse Sauvage, a limited edition photograph by Erica Lord
  • La Revolución! Printed t-shirts
  • Limited edition Letterpress Prints
  • Limited edition Serigraph Prints

Please consider supporting the collaboration. The Revolución is promising to be epic, stunning, and memorable. We hope you will join us and help us to reach our goal!

The Impact

Your contribution will help two of North America's notable and dynamic Indigenous artists to create a new body of work that explores Indigenous people, identity, culture, and the stories and profound symbolism of Darkness. This project is deeply significant to the artists; your support and funding would be invaluable, as it would allow them to finally carry out their ideas and aspirations, assisting in the movement of their concepts into final creation. As supporters of the Darkness project, you will have the first opportunity to view and own some of the new art works, created during the residence. Projects will involve the mediums of photography, video, performance, music, storytelling and print media. Your support and funding will help these two critically acclaimed and widely recognized contemporary artists add to their significant and important bodies of work; this collaboration means a great deal to both of these artists. Your support will not only help to promote the work of these two unique artists, but will also help promote contemporary Indigenous art, assisting in creating exhibition and screening possibilities.

Currently, you can see the work of Lord and TH at the National Gallery of Canada in the exhibition Sakahán: International Indigenous Art. This exhibition features the performance based photographic and video works of both artists, with a billboard project by TH featured in Ottawa’s ByWard district. You can find out more about this exhibition at: http://www.gallery.ca/sakahan/

You can also find more information about each artist and their work at their respective websites (2nd artist website removed per request):

http://www.ericalord.com

I invite everyone to spread the word and share this campaign with anyone that may be interested in the work of Lord, as well as anyone who may be interested in visual and performing arts, Indigenous culture or politics, the stories and dreams “the Boss” inspires, or Darkness, whether it be Darkness on the Edge of Town or Darkness in the North. Help me spread the word and find support for what I know will be an important project. Thank you for your consideration and support!

Your loyal and dedicated artist,

Erica Lord

*This campaign supported the partnership during June through July 2, the partnership unfortunately dissolved after July 11. I am still working on the artwork and will contact all supporters for options/alternative gifts due to this change. Due to this division my former partner has asked that I remove his name from the campaign and therefore is only referenced by initials or as "my former partner."

*Perks listing his name have been removed and those funders affected by the change to perks have and will be contacted and the printing and creation of work continues.
story_txt:
Darkness in the North: A Collaboration between Erica Lord & (former partner TH)
A Short Summary
Erica Lord and (former partner) TH are beginning a creative alliance of epic proportions! This summer, in partnership with Calgary’s The New Gallery and Edmonton’s The Works: Art & Design Festival, internationally recognized artists Erica Lord and (former partner TH) are collaborating on a series of exciting new works. They have sought this artistic partnership for years and starting in June, they are finally coming together for the first time! During June and July, Lord will be the artist in residence at The New Gallery, John Snow House (Calgary, AB). During this time, the artists will conceptualize the ideas they've outlined together, work with a variety of mediums, and conclude by collaborating and producing a series of new work including photography, video, printmaking, installation, new media, performance, and public interventions. A number of these performance works will be presented at The Works: Art & Design Festival, in Edmonton, June 20-July 2, 2013. The artists’ goal is to create a catalog and exhibition, which will include the documentation of these performances along with the other art pieces they create during this time. Lord and TH are seeking your support to help cover the cost of travel and production of art works, performances, and documentation. The New Gallery has generously supported us with housing and studio space; it is our responsibility to raise funds for the materials, production, and presentation. Please consider helping these two dynamic artists carry out their unique and exciting project by giving your support. In exchange for your help, Lord and (former partner TH)  are offering a number of gifts including art catalogs, Lord/TH stickers and shirts, and limited edition photographs, serigraph and letterpress prints.
Darkness in the North, Full Description
Darkness in the North is a collaborative art project inspired by Bruce Springsteen’s album, Darkness on the Edge of Town; Lord and TH found significant meaning in the songs and stories in Darkness, drawing connections to Indigenous peoples’ relationship with the dark, night, urban and rural experiences and the relationships connecting all of those elements. Using this inspiration as their launching point, the artists will collaborate on a series of new works at the John Snow House, where Lord will live, thanks to the support they are receiving from The New Gallery’s Artist in Residence program.
This project is a first collaboration by the artists, who first became friends several years ago when they were simultaneously highlighted as the feature artists on the Native American Indigenous Cinema and Arts website. Realizing they shared many artistic interests and important connections in their work, they hoped to some day work together—this project would finally allow the opportunity for this long-awaited collaboration.
The artists’ intention is to create a body of work involving ideas drawn from Springsteen’s Darkness album. Drawn to the universality of these stories, the artists found inspiration in the narratives of working class people, love and loss, the passion of youth, the reality of aging, the birth of new and the passing of older generations, individuality, community, and the rebellious spirit— all of these things connect us and helps create our identities. The artists’ process will begin with material experiments and intensive research in and around Calgary and Southern Alberta. They will connect and work with local artists, musicians, and artist run centers to create and present their art works. Lord and TH have planned to create a number of different series in a variety of mediums; their projects will include printmaking, photography, video, performance, site-specific works, and more. Since Lord and (former partner TH) have worked toward this union and collaboration for many years, they are confident that their driven and ambitious spirits will support both the scale and vision of this exciting project.
Erica Lord and (former partner TH) are both interdisciplinary media artists who have exhibited nationally and internationally and in many key exhibitions, they have been featured together. Erica Lord is a mixed-race Alaska Native artist who grew up between interior Alaska and Upper Michigan. TH is from Alberta and a member of the Blood Tribe, currently living and working in Calgary. Friends and colleagues for seven years, this project will be the first time Lord and TH will meet and work together.
What We Need & What You Get
The New Gallery and The Works Festival have generously provided us with the necessary bridge to bring us together at the creative think tank called the John Snow House in lovely Calgary, AB. We found a way to come together, we have the studio and time to develop our ideas, what remains is the production and presentation of the work. Creating and presenting work can get expensive and we have been working hard to come up with funding through every possible avenue; we chose to use IndieGoGo so we could offer some of our work in exchange for your valued support. Any size donation is valued and we’ve chosen a variety of gifts we believe you will like. Our goal of $3000 would cover the majority of our costs; if we are not able to reach our full goal, we will try and maximize the funds we do raise. The more money we raise, the more art we will be able to create and finish; our ideas are abundant, but our resources are limited. We are filled with excitement, creativity, and big ideas! Every donation will help some part of our art production—the more help we receive, the closer we will get to fulfilling our goal. Please consider supporting us in our project and goals; in exchange, you will have a part in the creation of important new works as well as a heartfelt thank you and a unique gift from both artists.
Ever wondered what went into creating an art piece? Your donation would support a variety of things including:

Supply and material costs for studio based works
Paper and substrate for prints, stickers, & posters
Ink and pigment/paint
Fabric and sewing materials
Photography and video documentation
Camera equipment rental—lenses & lighting
Audio recording equipment rental
Meals
Transportation costs 
As a thank you for your support, we are offering:

La Revolución! Stickers
GIVN'R- Perk pulled, alternatives currently being offered*
Danse Sauvage, a limited edition photograph by Erica Lord
La Revolución! Printed t-shirts
Limited edition Letterpress Prints
Limited edition Serigraph Prints
Please consider supporting the collaboration. The Revolución is promising to be epic, stunning, and memorable. We hope you will join us and help us to reach our goal!
The Impact
Your contribution will help two of North America's notable and dynamic Indigenous artists to create a new body of work that explores Indigenous people, identity, culture, and the stories and profound symbolism of Darkness. This project is deeply significant to the artists; your support and funding would be invaluable, as it would allow them to finally carry out their ideas and aspirations, assisting in the movement of their concepts into final creation. As supporters of the Darkness project, you will have the first opportunity to view and own some of the new art works, created during the residence. Projects will involve the mediums of photography, video, performance, music, storytelling and print media. Your support and funding will help these two critically acclaimed and widely recognized contemporary artists add to their significant and important bodies of work; this collaboration means a great deal to both of these artists. Your support will not only help to promote the work of these two unique artists, but will also help promote contemporary Indigenous art, assisting in creating exhibition and screening possibilities.
Currently, you can see the work of Lord and TH at the National Gallery of Canada in the exhibition Sakahán: International Indigenous Art. This exhibition features the performance based photographic and video works of both artists, with a billboard project by TH featured in Ottawa’s ByWard district. You can find out more about this exhibition at: http://www.gallery.ca/sakahan/
You can also find more information about each artist and their work at their respective websites (2nd artist website removed per request):
http://www.ericalord.com
I invite everyone to spread the word and share this campaign with anyone that may be interested in the work of Lord, as well as anyone who may be interested in visual and performing arts, Indigenous culture or politics, the stories and dreams “the Boss” inspires, or Darkness, whether it be Darkness on the Edge of Town or Darkness in the North. Help me spread the word and find support for what I know will be an important project. Thank you for your consideration and support!
Your loyal and dedicated artist,
Erica Lord

story:
Update 8/11 Total is at $1,350. :D  Thank you!  That takes the funding time to August.  The next $50 will go to purchasing an upgrade to Manga Studio EX 5.  After that, $40 will go for a new wacom pen, that's more comfy in my hand!  At $1,550, September is covered!  (Actually, September is covered, because I'm happy with how well this has gone!) You can also abuse my Amazon Work wishlist. :D

Note, I removed the Yiynova, because they are putting out a 24? inch version!!  I don't have any details at this time, but it's the LAST work equipment upgrade for the year.

Update:  Well, I didn't expect to hit goal so QUICKLY!! :D  Thank you!!  You can now contact me privately to use other ways to get perks!!  Just send an email to shivae ..dot.. studios at gmail .dot. dot. com.

Hello and welcome to the June/July Cyantian Chronicles Funding Run!

If you are not familiar with the Cyantian Chronicles, you can check it out online at cyantian.net.  It's a series of several different stories set in the same universe featuring anthropomorphic characters.  Each story has its own subarchive and I recommend you begin with the one marked Campus Safari.  The age rating is PG-13, on the low end.


If you are a reader, you know I'm having some laptop issues, as in, my laptop is old and it's not happy to be doing the workload I've been doing on it.  It's away for repairs and costing me every day it's away, so I'm going to run this little fundraiser to get myself back in the red and get some artwork done!  So this money, where's it going?  Supplies.  A portion toward my Note (This thing is so awesome for all my scripting needs!!)  A little put back for the Yiynova MSP19U I want ($600)  I don't intend to get it until this fall.  A little put back for the full mouth replacement.  Long story, genetics turned against me.  And some for routine groceries, gas and other stuff.  And now, on to the tiers!  (Nothing goes to ANYTHING fun unless the pledger wants it to, and those are limited. :D :D)

Little note here:  There will be another book drive a bit later.  For now, this is a small thing and new things are subject to be added when I get my tablet back.  It's supposed to come back after July 9th.  I'm tossing the idea around of printing the original Campus Safari one time in nice professional printed volumes.

The goal is set at $500, although my personal goal is $600, that's a standard $300 for each month of work.  The minimum is $500 and if it's not met, they take 9% instead of 4%, so I do need the minimum met.  The good thing is, I don't have to wait for funds!

Once this goal is met, I will be able to accept orders via mail and other methods.

Now for the perks!  I am restraining myself, because 1.  I am one person and 2.  I already have a lot of work I have to do, but if you don't want a plush, there are art options!  I may add new perks as it goes along.  For Indiegogo, you can select more than one perk by simply doing them one at a time or combine them in one and send me a note at the end of the campaign.

 Shipping:  

If you are outside the US, please add $5 to any tier you pick.  Items are small for a reason.  Larger items will have additional notes.

- Tiff

story:
My America 

My name is Ron Thompson...and I am an artist.  Currently, I am a MFA Candidate in Drawing at the University of Missouri, Columbia, about to graduate in December.  My Thesis exhibition reception is on November 1st, 2013...and I need to feed the people there!

Contrary to popular belief...Grad Students do not live a lavish lifestyle.  Because I will be funding the reception out of my pocket, I am asking for some support here.

What that means...

Catering, Advertising, Posters, DJ, Refreshments and travel back and forth between Kansas City and St. Louis, MO to advertise this event.

Thanks!

I want to give back to you as a thank you.  In case you would like to see my work,  website is http://cargocollective.com/ronaldthompson.  I want to make a few handmade items to say thank you.  Different levels of donations will receive one-of-a-kind pieces made personally for you.

story:
The Nuit Blanche Renegade Parade: March of Magical Creatures



The Canadian Ministry of Magic is issuing an emergency decree requiring all witches and wizards of sufficiently competent ability to assist in the tracking and capture of a flock of escaped magical creatures. Early reports are that a stampede swarm of 11 dragons and 14 hippogryphs,  alongside a pack of unregistered werewolves and rare herd of wild unicorns, are approaching the city of Toronto. The muggle population is on the verge of all-out panic as their meagre animal control measures and non-magical fire department have proven inefficacious in quenching dragon fire and treating werewolf bites.

The Ministry is rallying all magical forces at sunset on October third, Two Thousand and Fifteen.  Together, we will do battle with magical beings, beasts and monsters, and corral them back into the realms from whence they came.  

On account of Extraordinary and Dire Circumstances, the Minister has issued Decree 49, temporarily suspending the International Statute of Wizarding Secrecy and giving special authorization for the education of muggles in the magic arts and the distribution of wands to a limited number of muggle folk.  Any muggle who perishes by immolation, trampling, or live ingestation due to lack of sense, training, magical ability will be issued a full Indiegogo refund (payable to next of kin).

The Ministry thanks you for your cooperation.

WHAT IS THIS?

The Renegade Parade is a unique roaming art party.  Recognized as an official Scotiabank Nuit Blanche Project in 2012, it features a multi-platform parade float with DJs, art, and a massive mobile sound system. It's an annual art experience that's one part adventure, one part mystery, and just a dash of mischief.

What Your Contributions Pay For

The Parade is run entirely by volunteers and depends on the support of the community to happen.  The parade will only happen if we can raise $2,000 by Monday Sept 21.  Your contributions pay for:

  • The parade float truck, a custom built, multi-platform vehicle used for movie shoots that has an onboard generator and professional driver.
  • Audio and lighting rentals
  • Insurance
  • Paid-duty Police escort
  • Art installations and theme materials
  • Safety gear & sundry items

story:
Outline
What happens when you outsource every single step of a film production to cheap labor in low wage countries? What kind of creative piece will be generated out of this labour power if you just give it a budget to work from? „What People Do For Money“, the current video project of media artist Tillmann Ohm, is trying to find this out.



What is it about?
The so called micro job platforms are mainly offering services online like graphic design works or programming jobs for dumping prices. But you can also order video greetings or ask for creative writing. The range goes from fake costumer testimonials for your company's new product to bizarre pranks and birthday wishes.

„What People Do For Money“ is the main question in this experimental video work. It refers not only to the people offering their services but also to those who make use of it.

The cooperation with amateur and semi-professional service providers of the platforms is the focus of the project. The creative work generates itself from the financial investment. All steps will be created and produced by the members of the online markets.

And that’s how it will be produced...
The people offering their services on these micro job websites are not only the subject of the project but also its protagonists. The ordered screenplays (5 dollars, each 100 words) will be passed on to other providers to produce the scenes. But this is not where the outsourcing practice ends. The editing, post production, voice over, sound mixing, music composing and even film poster design, trailer, title song and advertising will be produced exclusively by people offering their low cost services online.




What happens with my money?
Even though the services are quite cheap, it requires many small tasks to produce the whole project. Every dollar will be invested in producing scenes or editing them. The funding goal is the amount of money considered as best to work with. But with every extra dollar the quality and length of the film can be increased. Basically, there is no limit.

The project will be out of control once started?
Not really. The producer and director is in control of every single step. That means editing the scripts, transforming everything into tasks (like stage directions) and managing the results. However, the final outcome is still unknown.




Is there a release date?
The world premiere will be on 15th of July 2016 as part of a group exhibition in Weimar, Germany. So, whatever happens until then, there will be a result which will be shared with you. Depending on the funding and total amount of the budget, it could be possible that the work proceeds after the screening. Never the less, you get the rewards within the promised time as it is independent to the film production.

Any risks?
The only risk will be the outcome since it's unknown. But hey, that's the exciting thing about it, right?

story:
Who are you and what is the dream you would bury?

My name is Claudine Cho, and I am a public artist working to help people transform pain into profound beauty. After the loss of my mom, I wondered if I'd ever feel pure joy again or if every moment after would be bittersweet. The dream I'd like to bury is that I'll get back to who I once was. I'd like to free myself to sit in the moments that are from the light and in doing so — allow myself to become whoever I need to be. 

At the beginning of the video above, you'll hear my mother's voice. "To live means to push through even when your dreams do not come true. Because to live means to stay alive. To live means to bloom as the flowers do and that flower is my present self." 

We held this conversation over a year ago, the night before I left home for Korea to pursue my own dreams, before either of us knew she had cancer. That night, I told her of my plans to create an interactive exhibition where people could see their unfulfilled dreams finally bloom. 

Dreams don't need to be fulfilled for them to have served their purpose. Sometimes, they're simply meant to guide you to yourself. 

I created "Garden of Buried Dreams" because as much as we love to dream, we all have a dream worth burying — of living up to our own expectations, of seeing our parents' dreams be fulfilled, of transforming into our best selves today.

At the close of our conversation, my mom says, "Let go of the dreams that have left you. Do not cling to them. Build your life from what remains." 

Although I say I created this for my mom, I feel she planted "Garden of Buried Dreams" in me.

story:
Summary

The Urban Lactation Project (ULP ) was founded in order to promote the rights of women who choose to breastfeed in public. The first stage focuses on conveying information about breastfeeding through an art exhibit that includes various aesthetic genres such as poetry, graphic design, printing, music, photography, sculpture and painting. There will also be an informational panel on both Saturdays with lactation experts from WIC and La Leche League San Francisco, mothers and artists. The event will be held from August 16-22, 2014 in San Francisco, California

The inspiration for this project comes from a unpleasant experience I had this year with an employee of the Department of Motor Vehicles of San Francisco who not only said "That 's Nasty," but also asked me to go to the bathroom or car (on a very hot day), or anywhere but the bench that is located outside of the building. According to her, I was “exposing myself” (her words) and she just wanted to protect the public from that. I then realized I live in a city with amazing resources (latching, peer support, biting, etc.), but I couldn’t find anyone doing public advocacy work.

Based on this experience we decided to expand the project into a second stage, the launching of the www.urbanlactionproject.org, a website where people can use social media to track and document their experience while breastfeeding at individual public locations such as restaurants, coffee shops, government buildings, beaches, parks, banks, etc. We believe this part of the project will hold lots of people accountable for their actions. At the same time it can serve as an educational tool for those who are unaware of the implications that come with making a woman feel uncomfortable while attempting to do what she perceive is best for the development of their child. Participating businesses will be given a sticker for their window so families can easily identify these places.

Contributions will help cover all of the expenses associated with curating a show, the creation of the website and printing costs of promotional material such as fliers, posters, tote bags and t-shirts.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise at least $3,000 to cover the following expenses

-Rent the venue for one week
-Conduct photo-shoots with local mothers
-Print all necessary material such as:
               * High-resolution (and large) pictures
               * Stickers
               * Posters flyers
               * Make t-shirts & tote bags
               * Letterhead paper to mail businesses asking them to become      breastfeeding friendly
               * Pay shipping and handling for some pieces that are coming from other states.
                * Printing costs associated with some of the works produced by other artists.
                * Materials for the large installations
                * Handyman fee   
                * One $500 scholarship for a breastfeeding mother returning to school (or already back in school)
                * Building the website and continue researching what methods might make it easier on lactating moms.
                * Provide food and water to volunteers and speakers
                * Miscellaneous

Perks
 We have a lot of neat perks such as t-shirts, sweatshirts, tote bags, stickers, sponsor status, and of course, our gratitude!

If we don't reach our goal, the funds will be used to cover the items on the list by the order of appearance.

The Impact

World Health Organization (WHO),National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion (CDC), the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) Women, Infants and Children (WIC) among many more leading health organizations all recommend infants should be breastfed exclusively through the first six months and continue breastfeeding for up to two years (or longer if mutually desired) accompanied with complimentary solid food.

In 2012 only 16 percent of American children were exclusively breastfed through the six-month mark and just 47 percent of all children received any breastfeeding at six months. These percentages have had a profound impact on the health of infants with higher rates of diabetes, obesity, leukemia, diarrhea, ear infections, respiratory infections and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). All directly associated with the consumption of infant formula.

The entire exhibit is constructed around the idea of creating an artistic intervention whose goals are to deconstruct and change the existing conditions that hurt breastfeeding mothers and their babies. We hope everything exhibited will engage the audience in the conversation about the existing gaps in breastfeeding support, protection and promotion. We want the public to embody the topic thus making them think about their personal contribution to the situation, whether positive or negative.

We believe that positive experiences helps increase the number of months a mother chooses to nurse. We truly believe this campaign can spark a  conversation that sees breastfeeding as natural and necessary for our society.


Other Ways You Can Help

-Spread the word and share this campaign with friends and on social media
-Contribute an art piece of your own
- Share a short story about your experience (or partner's) breastfeeding and why you believe it's important to protect
- Volunteer the day of the event
- and again, make some noise!! :)
