story:
Short Summary

When I was a little child, my grand-mother used to tell me stories for the people of her village. She was describing with passion their life and culture, so hard and difficult that many of them travelled abroad to have a better chance in life, and she showed me the handcrafts of her mother, embroidered with silk and gold, made beside the fireplace, on the light of a candle. I got really impressed from it and was proud when I wore the traditional costume in national feasts, looking forward to learn more for my ancestors.

When I grew up, I realized that every place in Greece has a unique traditional identity. Costumes varied from place to place reflecting the sense of aesthetics of the society and followed the morals and traditions of it. The textiles, the embroideries, the quality and quantity of clothes showed not only the financial situation of the family but also the historic continuity, the state of women in the society and the elegance of the person wearing them. Moreover the handcrafted jewels ornamenting the outfits, reflected the art of the greek goldsmiths and they were strongly connected with marriage, as they were offered by the groom as a sign of the betrothal and reward for the dowry.

I collected enough material to present you a book showing the treasures of the folk civilization taken out of a research that had more than ten years to be completed and documented by its bibliography, consisting of about 200 references from old books and personal testimonies. 125 colorful photos guide the reader through time and culture. Rare embroideries, dresses and textiles are taken off the closets and are photographed for first time, to inspire the artists and let the collectors know about them. Exclusive silver and gold-plated jewels, hidden for many years, are exposed to the lens and show their glamour and art of the greek goldsmiths. 19th century greek silver and gold coins, used then as decorative elements, constituted furthermore a display of wealth.

The traditional costumes presented in this book, seem to be the development and theevolution of the byzantine attitudes. The ancient greek chiton, the roman stolam and later the byzantine dalmatiki were substituted by the greek folk chemises. The later, richly decorated with floral and geometrical patterns seem also to have a relationship with ancient worships, since ancient gods’ symbols are found embroidered on the chemises’ hem to transfer fertility and beauty on the woman. All types of flowers parade on women’s clothes in exceptional makeshift designs and symbols like the triangle and the snake, found in many civilizations of the world like the Aztecs and Egyptians, can also be found on the garments to protect the superstitious Greeks from magic and evil eye, showing the global spread of symbols among human social groups. Moreover the jewels share with the ancient ones the same forms and designs, and furthermore the goldsmiths have made them with the same ancient techniques, showing the historical continuity of greek silverware.

The writer Asimina Nteliou comes from the island of Evia in Greece, where she lives. Passionate by the greek tradition, she is researching for more than ten years the authentic handcrafts of the greek folk civilization, photographing them and recording all the wisdom and morals of the Greek islanders, before the old ones die and the knowledge is lost. Her first book preserves the knowledge related to the folk costumes and jewels of her island and links it with the customs and the ancient and byzantine origin of Greek people. She is also fond of traditional dance and participates in a group performing greek traditional dance all over the world. She is married to Theofanis Ramiotis, a goldsmith and jewel conservator, who reproduces exact copies of the greek traditional jewels by old techniques and designs contemporary jewels inspired from the greek traditional culture. They both share the vision to preserve the greek folk civilization and promote it by a series of books and expositions all over the world, highlighting it as world heritage.


What We Need & What You Get

As my grand-mother did, I would like to tell you the story behind the greek traditional art, induce the memories and inspire you. I would also like to introduce to the lovers of folk civilizations a new undiscovered world which was not exposed to people before this effort takes place. I welcome you to this travel back to the past and induce you to fund this bilingual book (greek / english) so as it will be published and reach as many people as it can. 

In order to publish the book, some essential publishing work must be done. The book's design, printing and distribution has been assigned to a Greek publishing house (Fylatos Publishing). We plan to release the book simultaneously on more than 62 countries as an ebook and a printed book. The cost associated with the design of the book is 800 euros or 1000 usd. Furthermore the circulation of the printed book requires printing at least a small batch of premium quality books. This is planned to cost 250 euros or 300 usd. The cost of the designing and finalizing the ebook is estimated to be around 300 euros or 490 usd .

Every person that helps us gets something. Whether a thanks you note on an old fashioned post card or a valuable piece of jewelry inspired by the traditional art of Greece. 


The Impact

Publishing this book as a printed book and an ebook, is the only way to save, learn, protect, be inspired and continue the traditional culture and deliver it to the new generations of people, which is not only a matter of a small social group but a world heritage. 

Risks & Challenges

There is no actual risk. If anyone helps us, he/she will receive the perk and our gratidute. The book is planned to be published in January 2015 even if this campaing is unsuccesful. Any financial help though or even just sharing our campaing with your friends is greatly appreciated. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign with your friends and family.
story_txt:
Short Summary 

When
I was a little child, my grand-mother used to tell me stories for the
people of her village. She was describing with passion their life and
culture, so hard and difficult that many of them travelled abroad to
have a better chance in life, and she showed me the handcrafts of her
mother, embroidered with silk and gold, made beside the fireplace, on
the light of a candle. I got really impressed from it and was proud
when I wore the traditional costume in national feasts, looking
forward to learn more for my ancestors.

 When
I grew up, I realized that every place in Greece has a unique
traditional identity. Costumes varied from place to place reflecting
the sense of aesthetics of the society and followed the morals and
traditions of it. The textiles, the embroideries, the quality and
quantity of clothes showed not only the financial situation of the
family but also the historic continuity, the state of women in the
society and the elegance of the person wearing them.  Moreover the
handcrafted jewels ornamenting the outfits, reflected the art of the
greek goldsmiths and they were strongly connected with marriage, as
they were offered by the groom as a sign of the betrothal and reward
for the dowry. 


 I
collected enough material to present you a book showing the treasures
of the folk civilization taken out of a research that had more than
ten years to be completed and documented by its bibliography,
consisting of about 200 references from old books and personal
testimonies. 125 colorful photos guide the reader through time and
culture. Rare embroideries, dresses and textiles are taken off the
closets and are photographed for first time, to inspire the artists
and let the collectors know about them. Exclusive silver and
gold-plated jewels, hidden for many years, are exposed to the lens
and show their glamour and art of the greek goldsmiths. 19th
century greek silver and gold coins, used then as decorative
elements, constituted furthermore a display of wealth. 


The
traditional costumes presented in this book, seem to be the
development and theevolution
of the byzantine attitudes. The ancient greek chiton,
the

story:
BlueMagicRedDusk ∞ We Love You!

∞ Welcome! ∞

Our intention is to continue spreading and sharing that love through conscious content filling the Social Media sites with vibrant creativity and mind-expanding ideas! Buy the gift of a special Tarot Reading, Intuitive Channeling, Visionary Art, Energy Healing, or Custom Animation featuring YOU as FOR YOUR FRIENDS, FAMILY, AND YOURSELF!
We email every individual who buys a perk so we understand if it's a gift for you or someone else and all specific requests involving your chosen perk!

  • BlueMagicRedDusk is a Vision Art Divination Service that is created through the Cari-Creatures AKA Guardians of Maxwell Aston and the Tarot Readings, Intuitive Channeling, Soul Portraits and Energy Healing of Rafaella Angelica Nepales. We are both artists, channelers, and healers.
  • This campaign is a chance to take a giant step forward in creating a B.M.R.D. video Youtube channel of high-quality educational, FUNNY, and metaphysical videos. We want to create hilarious and deeply powerful videos that will help raise the planet's laughter and love frequency.
  • Contributors will help us achieve the sharing of fun conscious Social Media content with topics to help each other ride the wave of a big paradigm shift.

We are BlueMagicRedDusk!

I'm Max, an experienced artist who draws Cari-creatures, which I also call "Guardians". They are called Cari-Creatures because they are like a caricature, but they are whatever I feel about a person as far as their personality and current energetic state but in the form of a creature. The creatures look monstrous, surreal, and whimsical and encourage people to empower and stay true to themselves. My process of drawing these beings begins with me in a calm mental state, asking to meet with my guides. After I feel I am in deep enough meditation, I ask to meet their guide as a Guardian, and the images I receive in my imagination are always accurate! I will quickly draw a sketch and then be asked to be guided in completed what I started.

My Guardian, Zenith

I also work with my partner, Rafaella, a tarot reader, energy healer, artist and intuitive channeler. The soul portraits she creates are beautiful and colorful drawings using symbols that are based on a person's individual energy. All her readings and channelings are gifted with the intention of healing and aligning with one's higher self and spirit guides. She allows people to ask as many questions as they'd like to explore for their readings until they feel complete. Her interpretation of Tarot cards are not scary, but aware that life has challenges and unexpected events that may happen. 

An example of a Soul Portrait by Rafaella!

We can work separately but we love teaming up to do both readings and drawings. While I draw, Rafaella begins with her tarot reading. Then we switch and I offer my interpretation of my caricature while Rafaella gives energy healing quietly.


Testimonials

Our testimonials are just amazing! When we do events, the reactions of the guests are so exciting! Here are some of our favorites:

  • "Really beautiful. Both the channeling and portrait were a perfect connection to my energy and essence yet you weren’t telling me something I had heard before. Almost as if your reading reminded me to look again at the multidimensional layers of my essence, as we are all so much more than we appear. And when I get bogged down in the details of the earthly plane, I can easily forget the true nature of my higher self. The chakra reading and clearing was really spot on. And you knew that my dreams are tapping into the knowledge that I am trying to channell. Anyway, I could go on and on. You, my dear, are a gift of Light and Love. Thank you for sharing your profoundly creative essence with me."

    -Testimonial of Rafaella’s Service

  • "I have always admired Max’s talent as an artist….his work shows great depth and emotion. But his caricreature or "Guardian" drawing for me really blew me away! I’ll admit that at first glance the creature was rather frightening, but when Max explained to me what each feature represented, it touched my heart. I felt he captured the very essence of the creature inside me! Thank you Max for sharing this unique talent!" 

    -Testimonial of our combined services

  • "Thank you so much! You and raffie have such a unique take on readings and I feel like they’ve been helping me through some recent challenges." 

    -Testimonial of our combined services


We Need, You Receive

So, Let's get to it!
We are asking for $900 in order to obtain a new Canon EOS Rebel T5i DSLR Camera. Why? Well, upon researching many new DSLR's, we've come across this one as being the perfect example of what we're looking for. Here's the details:

  • This specific camera has a retail value of $849. The price we have chosen, $900, accounts for the percentage that is taken from Indiegogo at the end of the funding period.

The Butterfly Effect

Your contribution will help us to:

  • Greatly develop our online presence for humorous, fun, educational, and spiritual content. We believe in our mission to bring humor and intuition together and into the lives of all people. 
  • Continue our services and create more video blogs that document our events so that you can see our process.
  • De-stressing, clearing up any obstacles in your life, and hopefully providing a laugh. We don't want to only entertain. That isn't the point. We aim to help, provide assistance, and reconnect with others.

The Perks

There are many great perks you can receive (not in order, please check the perks to see the order depending on how much you donate):

  • Guardian
  • Mini-Guardian in color or Black and white

Mini-Guardian in Color



Mini-Guardian in Black and White

  • Custom animation
  • Custom song
  • Tarot Reading
  • Soul portrait


  • Example of a soul portrait done for a client
  • Custom song
  • Canvas prints
  • Reiki Healing
  • You, drawn in our first video doing something silly
  • Holiday greeting card surreal landscape

Obstacles

However, there are always risks involved:

  • We risk having to delay our project. Not getting fully funded will keep people in the dark about us and what we do. Having this camera gets our foot in the door for bringing you great content. Without full funding, we won't be able to bring you big projects and full ideas yet, which is something we are also really looking forward to.
  • If we don't receive funding for our project, we will invest all the money that we receive into this new DSLR. No matter what, you're helping us out tremendously!

You Can Always Help

If you can't contribute, there are still ways that you can help us achieve our goal!:

  • You can like us on Facebook! The address is: https://www.facebook.com/bluemagicreddusk.
  • Want to share the campaign with someone? Copy the campaign URL  and paste it into an email or social media update to show your support!

A big thank you from the bottom of our hearts,

Max and Rafaella

story:
Summary:

Saratoga Springs artist, Sharon Crute, known for her equine paintings, has had some really bad luck. A couple of days ago, while driving to a plein air art competition, her fully loaded van caught fire, and incinerated everything in it -- canvases, easels, brushes, paints. The whole works.

I'm a videographer/writer who is connected to the art scene in Saratoga Springs through Amejo Amyot, owner and operator of the Beekman Street Studios, where Sharon's studio is. Like many artists, Sharon isn't exactly flush with cash, so contributions will help her get back to painting.


What We Need & What You Get

All the money will go to replacing the art supplies that Sharon lost in the fire, and getting her back to painting. $1,000 will buy canvases, easels, paints (oils and acrylics), brushes, thinners, turpentine, and the other things that fine artists need to create paintings..

I'm not exactly sure what perks we can offer, other than tremendous, heartfelt thanks for your generosity, and if you contribute $50 (USD) or more and provide a street address, I will handwrite and post a personal note of thanks to you in the mail.

Even if we don't reach $1,000, every dollar is going to help. It's all going to Sharon Crute.


The Impact

We all know the world needs more art, and Sharon Crute's work is worth promoting. Let's get her back up and painting, and let's do it fast.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute cash, how about sharing the campaign on your social media pages, or your blog?

story:
Hello everybody!

This is Gene-Manuel from The Whirling Blog. My ancient computer finally could take it no more and stopped working. Everything I do, my art and editing The Whirling Blog, depends on my having a computer. Everything!

Help me continue my work & expand The Whirling Blog!

Any amount raised here will go towards the purchase of a new computer, preferably a Mac.  This will help me continue to not only work on my art, but continue to grow The Whirling Blog going forward. 

What will you get?

Whirling Art of course!! If you’re going to help me create my art, then I think you ought to get some art in return. Check out the perks on the right to find out all of the art that I will be creating just for this campaign!

    

      

  

I’m currently living a dream every single day. 

I get to create art that in turn brings joy to so many people. I have also been able to create a space for an entire community of incredible people to gather and receive uplifting and inspiring information, via The Whirling Blog. 

By contributing you get some of my art and help expand not only my work but the work of so many brilliant contributors!  

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell every one you know! Tweet it. Share it on Facebook. Send a quick email to your entire list of friends with the link to this campaign. Use the handy Indiegogo share tools! Anything you can do, will be appreciated more than you’ll ever know.

story:
Ebenezer/herchurch Lutheran (herchurch) refers to the Divine Presence through many names and metaphors. More than 50,000 years ago the sacred one was called mother.  Breaking recent tradtion from male diety, this mural aims to herald the return of the feminine divine in modern Christian, interfaith and feminist spirituality.

Please support celebrating goddess imagery on herchurch - a purple Lutheran Church -because for many God/ess is a holy parent, not just a male parent. As well she is a lover, friend, sustainer, birther, Wisdom and life giver. This is not another image celebrating patriarchy, this mural honors the feminine divine.

Renowned artist Sybil Erden is donating her time and vision to produce a painting that will be 16 feet by 64 feet, rising above San Francisco's busy Portola Drive! Attached via panels to the East face of the purple herchurch tower, this mural promises to be a focal point in the world famous San Francisco mural collection.


The mural will consist of 32 panels (4x8 feet each). So if each individual panel
were purchased as a separate painting for its gallery value (of some $10,000) we are talking about a gift from the artist in terms of hundreds of hours and creative value of at least $320,000. But to create this masterpiece, all we need to raise is $35,000 to cover basic supplies and expenses. We are raising money for the painting/creation supplies, transportation and installation.

The dream is to share the beauty to all who pass and prophetically envision our mission of rebirthing the divine feminine in ourselves, the church and the world.

Sybil has now produced detailed scale drawings and has begun
the undercoating on some of the panels. Ten mural panels will be completed and transported to herchurch and displayed at the November 2-4 herconference. We need your support to make this vision a reality.

See the gallery images for the full mural design. 

A recent viewer was brought to tears when ecountering the divine feminine through these portraits of MotherGod, the Black Madonna, Christ-Sophia and Goddess' transforming chakras in each of us.  Let your heart be so moved!

Ten mural panels will be completed and transported to herchurch and displayed at the November 2-4 herconference. We need your support to make this vision a reality.
See the gallery images for the full mural design. 
A recent viewer was brought to tears when ecountering the divine feminine through these portraits of MotherGod, the Black Madonna, Christ-Sophia and Goddess' transforming chakras in each of us.  Let your heart be so moved!

story:
Hi, I'm Beatrix Antal. I deal with glass engraving.

                          

         
I live in Hungary, in Budapest, and glass engraving is here a less known art. I have learned the technique from British artists, I've gained my whole knowledge from the internet, and forgeign sites, as in Hungarian there is not much information about it.

I would like to change that, and have edited a tutorial, which I would like to publish, in first stance in my homeland, as a book and as online material. There are a lot of people interested, who have engraving as a hobby, but they do not know what to order, and where from, vhat techniques can be used, and so on. This is why I would like to help them in their creative work, and popularise this wonderful art.



In order to improve myself, I need to improve my assets  and need a bigger investment. This is why I kindly ask you help.

I would like to move to a bigger workshop, where there would be place for my glass furnace, and for different grinding machines. I plan it a workshop-gallery, where I could also show and sell my art and works. I have a lot of ideas, which I would like to realize.

My further goal is to enter the international market.

My clients are primarily private persons, and I work for specific orders. If my projects succeeds, I could create my own glass collections and promote them worldwide. Primarily they would be home decorations - glass bowls, vases, sculptures, image compositions.



I've got from my current clients very positive feedback, as such personalized engraved glass gifts give great pleasure.

As soon as my project succeeds, you can see my work on the website, and everyone who helped in the realization of the project, will have a life-long discount. This means various discounts, depending on the donation amount, independently from any gifts.

I will be constantly publicize the details of the realization, and for those who themselves are interested in glass engraving beyond the gift, I will send the tutorial. You just have to mention it separately.

The web-shop will be only ready when the products were produced with the new techniques.
The inverstment rate, of course, will be impiemented
depending on the collected amount.

Investment details:

- Workshop renting, remodeling, equipment

- Furnace

- 2 pcs big grinding machinges

- glasses, materials


If the donations reach beyond the planned bugdet the extra amount will be used for:
- 3 pcs manual micro-powered grinding machines
- additional materials and glasses

A couple from my works:


Offerings:


Risks & Challenges


If I can collect less money as I need, I can't buy all of the necessary equipment, and I can't modernize my workshop. The most important for me is the junnace.

The time limit of shipping could take longer than usual and the package include fragile terms.

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone! My name is Dylan McHugh and I am a visual artist based in Vancouver BC. I have been working with ceramics as a professional artist for 8 years. Recently, I have been accepted to be a part of a rare residency at the Banff Centre: WOOD/SODA/FIRE/BANFF, starting at the end of April for one month!

This residency is an opportunity to work alongside other wood and soda fire enthusiasts under the tutelage of Robin DuPont and Dan Murphy. Two extraordinary ceramic masters of atmospheric firings. To be able to learn, create, share ideas, techniques and inspirations, and be inspired by the stunning surroundings of the Rocky Mountains will be an incredible once in a life time experience.

The Banff Centre is the largest arts and creativity incubator in the world! This opportunity will have a profound impact on my practice and I want to share it with you!

What I Need 

Banff Centre is generously granted me a scholarship, covering 50% of the residency costs while I am there, not including materials and travel.

I need additional $2000.

$1600 to cover the remaining residency costs: facilities, equipment, food and accommodation.

$400 to cover material expenses for the residency: clay, slips, glazes and plaster.

100% of the donations will go towards the residency expenses.

In return for your amazing support, you will have my undying gratitude and receive one of the many offered perks, all of which will be made from my time at this residency!

What You Get

I will be making a limited edition of whisky related vessels during my residency and in return for your amazing support I will be including them as perks!

The Impact

This opportunity is a special one for me, giving me a chance to learn and grow as an artist through this unique experience. I will have access to high fire soda and wood fire kilns for and intensive period of time amongst the support of experts in the field. This concentrated period will support the development of a new body of work that not be easily realized without this residency.

This new body of work is inspired by folk pottery and grass roots whisky traditions of the Southern States.

Drawing from the history and convergence of these practices I will create a series of whisky related vessels: jugs, flasks, bottles and cups. Using the same atmospheric firings as the Southern folk potters, the wood and soda firings this residency will provide are critical to the fruition of this body of work, both aesthetically and conceptually.

Thank you! 

To everyone who spreads the word and shares my campaign! Especially those of you who are able to donate to this exciting journey!

Much Love, Dylan

story:
Short Summary

We are a not-for-profit student organization on Purdue University's campus that celebrates the BBC television show Doctor Who. It is our dream to build a life-sized TARDIS to use for club promotions and events. We wish to have this completed for our first big charity event, which is the Purdue/American Cancer Society's Relay for Life event in April. Our campaign is important to us to bring club members and our community together to create something meaningful that will represent the combined efforts of the current club as a gift to future members. Contributors will help us achieve a dream we have had since the inception of the club. Without the help of contributors we could not fully realize this amazing project. Being a not-for-profit student organization our activities rely heavily on the generosity of those who love Doctor Who and want to share in the experience that is a 50 year celebration of travels through time and space.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is how $660 breaks down:

  • The wood for the TARDIS will cost $275
  • The hardware will cost $100
  • Paint will cost $100
  • Decorative details will cost $150
  • The remaining $35 will go towards a plaque that will commemorate all those who put time and effort into this project
  • None of the money will be paying for labor or time, just the materials required. Students will be volunteering their time over Spring Break to make this dream a reality
  • Any money that exceeds our goal or price of construction will go towards rewarding the members that donated their time and hard work to this project

Rewards:

  • Those who donate over $50 will receive a signed, framed photo of the completed project in addition to a surprise gift. 
  • Those who donate $100 will get their name on the commemorative plaque inside the TARDIS. In addition they will receive the $50 perk.
  • Those who donate $500 and can arrange their own transportation get a free professional photo shoot with the TARDIS, in addition to the lower level awards.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating please share the link to this project with those who would like to be part of this adventure (though time and space). Every share and dollar counts toward reaching our goal.

story:
Who We Are

We are graduating seniors in the BFA sculpture program at SUNY Purchase. We are very passionate about our work but are ready to expand out of the academic realm and into the R E A L W O R L D. We are in a sculpture program, but we do not limit ourselves to one medium. Video, performance, objects, electronics, fibers, sound, net-art, and mixed-media can describe the types of things we work with. On May 7, we are hosting an experimental event night at Abrons Art Center in New York City. We need your help to fund everything that goes into making a show happen. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our temporary one-night exhibition at Abrons Art Center will not necessarily display our personal bodies of work, but rather a collaborative performance-based event. This will include videos, performances, props, and experimental lectures. What should you expect? Expect the unexpected. We need funding to make this night happen.

  • We need $2000 to cover our costs of transportation, equipment, and to make an exhibition catalog. We cannot pay for this on our own.
  • What do you get in return? Suprises! Stickers! Posters! Art! T-Shirts! Personal philanthropic joy!
  • No matter how much we raise, we will use the money towards this project. We hope to reach our goal so we can fund everything we need to make this event night happen.

The Impact

Your contribution will support the arts as well as artists who are just starting out. We need as much support as we can get! We have worked hard for the last four years both academically and artistically and are ready to show the world what we have learned. By donating, you will be supporting us as artists and students as we finish this leg of our personal journeys.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please share our campaign with friends on social media. Please help us reach our goal!

Thanks,

SUNY Purchase BFA Sculpture Class of 2015

story: I have a very understanding landlord who has been willing to work with me during my difficulty, however i have fallen further and further behind, and need to find a way to catch up to avoid eviction. I have much original art and several records and cds from my large discography available as perks for donations, at present age another stint of homelessness seems extreme and i wish to avoid this at all costs.

story:
What Are We Up To?

@Divine is an interactive grouping of new installation works and collaborative design by 11 local artists of widely varying backgrounds, disciplines and techniques.

The artists have taken an overgrown lot of unused land with a view of Downtown New Orleans and are creating an altar of the elements, an amalgam of personal treasures and venerated imagery.

The installation will host a variety of events throughout it's run, including fundraisers for local arts programs, children's workshops and a late evening opening celebration on October 24th.


@DIVINE will feature new works from:

Rahn Broady
Erika Busciglio
Nicho Busciglio
Elizabeth Eckman
Fat Kids
Brent Houzenga
MRSA
Sarah Rose
Ruby T
Adam Tourek
Francis Wong

The exhibition and community altar is a part of the third biennial international art gathering of Prospect New Orleans. The P.3+ program is directed at highlighting and promoting concurrent exhibitions and arts events put up by local artists. We feel it is important to represent a comprehensive cross section of local artists while the city is hosting national and international artists for this three month long event.

What We Need

By and far, most of the materials the artists are using to produce the installation have come out of pocket or have been sourced from the site, the streets and local shorelines. However, we need to secure funding in order light the space. This is going to be an entirely outdoor exhibition and lighting the massive lot may prove challenging, both logistically and financially. Alongside the electric lighting elements we plan to illuminate the space with candles. Lots of them. Really and truly, we need money for candles and wax. You'll thank us later.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are attempting to gather the last of the supplies we need to finish working on this collaborative exhibition and there are still so many things we need! Namely:

gnarly wood
oxidized iron/steel (anything this side of transportable)
rope (lots!) and/or cable and/or chain
wire (assorted)
anything shiny (glass, mirror, crystal, glitter, copper, faerie shards)
fabric & burlap
paint! (any; rattle can, house, enamel, leftovers)
lighting elements and extension cords
candles & wax (so many)
other junk!!!

If you have stuff hanging around that can be donated or if you have a line on where we can retrieve any of the above materials please give us a heads up by sending us a message! There's 11 of us and many of us are scroungers, but it's been a rough summer y'all. Also, I hope you like altars!

story:
Our Crowdfunding Campaign has moved to: https://www.hatchfund.org/project/pyramid_of_the_dead_burning_man_2017

 

Overview Espanol

La Pirámide de los Muertos es un altar comunitario y un proyecto de arte participativo que invita a los artistas individuales a ser parte de una instalación de grandes dimensiones. La Pirámide es un proyecto muy cercano y querido para nosotros y ha sido parte integrante de llevar la cultura mexicana de Día de Muertos al Festival de La Calaca cada año en San Miguel de Allende en un contexto creativo-Este año tenemos el honor de compartir este increíble proyecto en el mayor festival de arte del mundo, Burning Man. Participa y contribuye. Todas las donaciones deducibles de impuestos!

 

 

Death is a Muse

The Pirámide is comprised of 128 Mexican hand-crafted tin frames called “nichos,” each showcasing custom artwork and images as tributes to those who have passed or honouring the concept of death. Participants are invited to honour personal loved ones, create homages to cultural icons or paint your own imagery of death in these 1.5m high x 1m wide frames. We believe channeling loss into art is a life-affirming experience, and the shared communal structure brings us together to admire and revere the beauty that results from death. participate and contribute! All donations tax deductible!  For more information on The Pirámide, click here to read about us in Vice.

 

The Structure

The Pirámide will be a climbable structure so you can get up close and personal with your artwork or loved one. The Pirámide is five levels high, following ancient pyramid-building methods of the Meso-Americans. The structure be will be approximately 20 feet high, and 30 by 20 feet in width and depth. At night, a custom projection mapping will illuminate the surface of the work. In addition, the enclosed space within the structure will serve as a shrine —where visitors will be encouraged to hang out and leave offerings to their own deceased loved ones, creating a communal space for meditation, reflection and remembrance.

 

You Can Create

We are calling all artists from Burning Man and beyond to sign up to contribute to this piece. Become a considered contributing artist by sending some sample artworks to piramide@lacalacafestival.org or guarantee your spot on The Pirámide for your artwork or loved one by donating $350 or more. We are also offering the opportunity to create a personal or public prayer session within the inner shrine of The Pirámide itself.

 

Ways to Help

Your TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donations cover: the materials; building The Pirámide's structure; the hand-crafted tin frames / nichos, prints of the artwork; AV equipment; lighting and decoration; and transport from Mexico.  We will be crossing the U.S./Mexican border with most of our materials, and need all the support we can get, as we build a truly brilliant installation to share with our unified community, one that is spiritually free of division.

 

Perks

Here is a sneak peak at some of the Pyramid of the Dead Perks.

Pendant Nicho Necklace


Receive a "nicho" pendant designed in the same style as the metal nicho frames of the Pyramid itself. Hand-crafted in Mexico, these one-of-a-kind keepsakes were designed specifically for donors of this project. Redemption available on site at Burning Man 2017 or shipped in October 2017.

Team T-Shirt

Get a custom T-shirt, designed by the amazing La Calaca Festival Design Team! Be the envy of all your friends with this super cool, 100% cotton black shirt with our trippy branding on the front. Redemption available on site at Burning Man 2017 or shipped in October 2017.

Festival Poncho

     

Get a limited edition Poncho designed for Burning Man 2017. The Poncho is a bone-white/rigor-mortis grey, cotton blend knit, made in Guanajuato, Mexico. It is custom-printed with vibrant sacred geometry designs. Created by the award-winning La Calaca Design Team. Redemption available on site at Burning Man 2017 or shipped in October 2017.

WAKE Up! Let's Celebrate!

In the spirit of Day of the Dead, we'll throw a party in honor of our biggest patron! Revel to 20,000 watt sound from the newest art car in BRC, ¡AXOLOTL! parked by The Piramide! Design the party with us or let us plan your 2-hour festivity. CDJ on board; date, time & music direction at the discretion of The Piramide. DJ provided if needed.

 

Meet The Team

Tomas Burkey - Creator Pirámide of the Dead / Co-Founder La Calaca Festival

Tomás Bürkey is the creator of Piramide de Muertos. He is a Chilean-American multi-disciplinary artist with a career spanning over twenty years in the fields of painting, sculpture, installation, music and theater. He is also a co founder of the La Calaca festival. He has made Mexico his home for over 10 years, where the profound culture and ancient history has influenced his artistic and spiritual life deeply.

 

Klaudia Oliver - Contributor / Co-Founder La Calaca Festival

Klaudia seeks to foster creativity and consciousness through art, culture and unique experiences, creating spaces where people and ideas are incubated and converge. Klaudia is the founder of La Calaca festival in Mexico and co founder of La Calaca Camp at burning man she is a 10 year Burning Man veteran and licensee of TEDxBlackRockCity.

 

Lynn Rawden - Design & Communications Director / Co-Founder La Calaca Festival

Lynn works professionally in design, publishing  and fashion. She is one of the original founders of the La Calaca Festival and co-founder of Piñata's Revenge camp at Burning Man where somehow she manages the kitchen!  2017 will be her 11th year at Burning Man; she looks forward to performing as a percussionist with the Jim Reynolds Band as well as DJ-ing atop her camp's art car Axolotl as MC Meow. She will also be hosting sisterhood circles, exploring the light, off-beat aspects of ritual.

 

Ali Agus - Marketing & Build Team

Californian born, Indonesian raised, Mexico residing Ali Agus a.k.a. Turtle Crawl (Kura) has been burning since 2010 and is a Jack-of-All trades. He is a maker, a builder, an event organiser and a graphic designer occasionally moonlighting as a DJ under the monikers Ali from Bali and DJ Aux. Ali has worked and volunteered on numerous projects at Burning Man after falling in love with Black Rock City 7 years ago. He has contributed to Pinatas Revenge Theme Camp, The Axolotl Art Car, Center Camp and will also be a Temple Guardian this year. 

 

Ben Brill - Production Manager, Mathematical Comedian

A Canadian living in Mexico, Ben Brill (Saturn) has been  burning  since 2008. He’s helped build the Axolotl car, co-  produces  TEDxBRC on the playa and generally finds Burning  Man to be the most expansive, surreal community to ever manifest for one week. Always up for a dusty challenge, passionate about  technology, culture, spirit and the future;  Saturn will be getting  down and dirty building the Pirámide de  Muertos in the elements during early entry to Black Rock City  2017.

Video Mapping MX - Digital Mapping Team

 

A Mexican based creative laboratory integrated by a network of local companies and young designers that work together in a comprehensive platform fusing art, design and technology. videomapping,mx

La Pirámide es un proyecto muy cercano y querido para nosotros y ha sido parte integrante de llevar la cultura mexicana de Día de Muertos al Festival de La Calaca cada año en San Miguel de Allende en un contexto creativo-Este año tenemos el honor de compartir este increíble proyecto en el mayor festival de arte del mundo, Burning Man. Participa y contribuye. Todas las donaciones deducibles de impuestos!  Death is a MuseThe Pirámide is comprised of 128 Mexican hand-crafted tin frames called “nichos,” each showcasing custom artwork and images as tributes to those who have passed or honouring the concept of death. Participants are invited to honour personal loved ones, create homages to cultural icons or paint your own imagery of death in these 1.5m high x 1m wide frames. We believe channeling loss into art is a life-affirming experience, and the shared communal structure brings us together to admire and revere the beauty that results from death. participate and contribute! All donations tax deductible!  For more information on The Pirámide, click here to read about us in Vice. The StructureThe Pirámide will be a climbable structure so you can get up close and personal with your artwork or loved one. The Pirámide is five levels high, following ancient pyramid-building methods of the Meso-Americans. The structure be will be approximately 20 feet high, and 30 by 20 feet in width and depth. At night, a custom projection mapping will illuminate the surface of the work. In addition, the enclosed space within the structure will serve as a shrine —where visitors will be encouraged to hang out and leave offerings to their own deceased loved ones, creating a communal space for meditation, reflection and remembrance. You Can CreateWe are calling all artists from Burning Man and beyond to sign up to contribute to this piece. Become a considered contributing artist by sending some sample artworks to piramide@lacalacafestival.org or guarantee your spot on The Pirámide for your artwork or loved one by donating $350 or more. We are also offering the opportunity to create a personal or public prayer session within the inner shrine of The Pirámide itself. Ways to HelpYour TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donations cover: the materials; building The Pirámide's structure; the hand-crafted tin frames / nichos, prints of the artwork; AV equipment; lighting and decoration; and transport from Mexico.  We will be crossing the U.S./Mexican border with most of our materials, and need all the support we can get, as we build a truly brilliant installation to share with our unified community, one that is spiritually free of division. PerksHere is a sneak peak at some of the Pyramid of the Dead Perks.Pendant Nicho NecklaceReceive a "nicho" pendant designed in the same style as the metal nicho frames of the Pyramid itself. Hand-crafted in Mexico, these one-of-a-kind keepsakes were designed specifically for donors of this project. Redemption available on site at Burning Man 2017 or shipped in October 2017.Team T-ShirtGet a custom T-shirt, designed by the amazing La Calaca Festival Design Team! Be the envy of all your friends with this super cool, 100% cotton black shirt with our trippy branding on the front. Redemption available on site at Burning Man 2017 or shipped in October 2017.Festival Poncho     Get a limited edition Poncho designed for Burning Man 2017. The Poncho is a bone-white/rigor-mortis grey, cotton blend knit, made in Guanajuato, Mexico. It is custom-printed with vibrant sacred geometry designs. Created by the award-winning La Calaca Design Team. Redemption available on site at Burning Man 2017 or shipped in October 2017.WAKE Up! Let's Celebrate!In the spirit of Day of the Dead, we'll throw a party in honor of our biggest patron! Revel to 20,000 watt sound from the newest art car in BRC, ¡AXOLOTL! parked by The Piramide! Design the party with us or let us plan your 2-hour festivity. CDJ on board; date, time & music direction at the discretion of The Piramide. DJ provided if needed. Meet The TeamTomas Burkey - Creator Pirámide of the Dead / Co-Founder La Calaca FestivalTomás Bürkey is the creator of Piramide de Muertos. He is a Chilean-American multi-disciplinary artist with a career spanning over twenty years in the fields of painting, sculpture, installation, music and theater. He is also a co founder of the La Calaca festival. He has made Mexico his home for over 10 years, where the profound culture and ancient history has influenced his artistic and spiritual life deeply. Klaudia Oliver - Contributor / Co-Founder La Calaca FestivalKlaudia seeks to foster creativity and consciousness through art, culture and unique experiences, creating spaces where people and ideas are incubated and converge. Klaudia is the founder of La Calaca festival in Mexico and co founder of La Calaca Camp at burning man she is a 10 year Burning Man veteran and licensee of TEDxBlackRockCity. Lynn Rawden - Design & Communications Director / Co-Founder La Calaca FestivalLynn works professionally in design, publishing  and fashion. She is one of the original founders of the La Calaca Festival and co-founder of Piñata's Revenge camp at Burning Man where somehow she manages the kitchen!  2017 will be her 11th year at Burning Man; she looks forward to performing as a percussionist with the Jim Reynolds Band as well as DJ-ing atop her camp's art car Axolotl as MC Meow. She will also be hosting sisterhood circles, exploring the light, off-beat aspects of ritual. Ali Agus - Marketing & Build TeamCalifornian born, Indonesian raised, Mexico residing Ali Agus a.k.a. Turtle Crawl (Kura) has been burning since 2010 and is a Jack-of-All trades. He is a maker, a builder, an event organiser and a graphic designer occasionally moonlighting as a DJ under the monikers Ali from Bali and DJ Aux. Ali has worked and volunteered on numerous projects at Burning Man after falling in love with Black Rock City 7 years ago. He has contributed to Pinatas Revenge Theme Camp, The Axolotl Art Car, Center Camp and will also be a Temple Guardian this year.  Ben Brill - Production Manager, Mathematical ComedianA Canadian living in Mexico, Ben Brill (Saturn) has been  burning  since 2008. He’s helped build the Axolotl car, co-  produces  TEDxBRC on the playa and generally finds Burning  Man to be the most expansive, surreal community to ever manifest for one week. Always up for a dusty challenge, passionate about  technology, culture, spirit and the future;  Saturn will be getting  down and dirty building the Pirámide de  Muertos in the elements during early entry to Black Rock City  2017.Video Mapping MX - Digital Mapping Team A Mexican based creative laboratory integrated by a network of local companies and young designers that work together in a comprehensive platform fusing art, design and technology. videomapping,mx

story:
Who we are

Washington Park Association of Hudson County, Inc. (WPA) is an independent, community based, volunteer run, 501(c)(3) nonprofit providing services and benefits to more than 1,000 community residents.

Our annual event - Washington Park LIVE! - is increasingly valued as a vital cultural resource. Unquestionably, in Union City and Jersey City, there are few arts and cultural activities that are as varied or attract as many people as Washington Park LIVE! More than 100 professional artists showcase, interact, excite, teach and inspire residents throughout the day.

A sample of 2013's program includes: Flash Mob Opera, Recylce Fashion workshop, Pop Up Shakespeare, Urban Dance Off, Band Stand Live Music, DJ's, "Ask Granny" geneological workshops, and Movie Shorts.

What We Need & What You Get

As little as $5 donation helps us work with the community to present a free high quality and participatory arts program. But consider this - $20 gets you a free WPA membership with tote bag!

Washington Park LIVE! is especially great for Jersey City and Union City - two cities that don’t have highly visible art identities but do contain rich cultural resources.  Washington Park LIVE! helps our community:

  • bring family members to grow together, share positive experiences, and discover new ideas and talents
  • enjoy the excitement associated with the arts
  • by sparking a bond between residents
  • explore and share its rich and varies cultural heritage
  • by stimulating local business

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Can't make a donation at this time? No problem.  We need your help in other ways.

Please share or make some noise about our Indiegogo campaign on Facebook or by email.

Volunteer on the day.  We need lots of help with set up, artist wrangling, people direction, strike, welcome committees. Email us through Facebook.

story:
Siegrid Bangyay began discovering the art of ceramics in 2000 learning the craft with American artist Archie Stapleton.

For 2 ½ years Stapleton taught Siegrid and the other apprentices the art and science of the traditional ceramic craft.  They learned to identify clay deposits and how to dig and process their own clay.  They studied the painstaking process of developing and testing local clay and glaze ingredients.  They learned to throw forms on the potter’s wheel, and to build and fire kilns.  Most importantly, they learned the continuing process of experimenting with new materials, techniques, forms, and glazes, a process that allows them to combine the traditional influences of Chinese heirloom pottery with those gained from modern artists and their own creative impulses.

Siegrid’s work has been displayed in numerous galleries and museums, including the Pinto Gallery in Antipolo, the CAV Wine Shop and Gallery and the LeSouffle Restaurant and Gallery in Manila and the the BenCab Museum, Breathing Space Gallery, Maryknoll Gallery, and Hill Station Restaurant in Baguio.  Her work was displayed in the Ayala Museum’s 2009 “Ring of Fire” exhibit featuring the work of prominent Southeast Asian ceramic artists, and she will make her international debut at the “Earth and Fire” exhibit of Contemporary Southeast Asian Pottery at the Workhouse Arts Center in Lorton, Virginia, USA in October 2014.

This is a rare opportunity for an artist from a remote area of the Philippines to emerge on a global stage.


The purpose of this project is to raise funds to allow Siegrid to attend the exhibition and participate in the workshops associated with it.  The proposed schedule:

October 6, 2014: Fly from Manila to Washington DC

Oct 8-14: Exhibit opening and workshops at the Workhouse Arts Center

Oct 15: Travel to Sewanee, TN

Oct 16-24: Work with Archie Stapleton

Oct 25: Return to Washington DC area

Oct 26: Return to the Philippines

The exhibit venue will provide accommodation for 3 days. Aside from that time, hotel accommodation will be necessary unless we can identify a potential host living close enough to the venue to allow daily commuting. Accommodation and food in Sewanee will be covered.

Proposed budget:

International travel Manila/Washington DC round trip):  $1500

Shipping of works for exhibit  $1000

Expenses:      $800

Contingencies  $400

Total fundraising target  $3700 

Siegrid’s artistic life is complemented by extensive involvement in community and development work.  She has worked for a number of NGOs, including A Single Drop Foundation (www.singledrop.org) training community residents to build and use bio-sand water filters, and Earth Day Network Philippines (www.earthdayphilippines.org), as community coordinator for projects installing hydraulic ram water pumps.  She’s a founder and board member of the Sagada Solid Waste Association, and has served as barangay (village) secretary in her home village of Dagdag.  Siegrid has worked as local counterpart to a Peace Corps Volunteer’s environmental education projects, and was a project design and management trainer for Peace Corps Philippines groups.

This campaign has been initiated by close friends and former co-workers of Siegrid’s.  We are confident that through the network of people that she has guided, hosted, trained, and worked with, we can raise the funds to bring Siegrid to this symposium.
